text: hello everyone
Morning everyone
:snowflake: :coffee: :coffee: :coffee: :snowflake:
Morning
hi!
hola
hi!
am I the only person that hates linters?
well actually forget that, I dont
I hate the way some people employ them*
_eslint_ needs a lot of taming
yes
and its SOOO configurable
yeah i just got to a happy place with my config and then started using typescript :stuck_out_tongue:

```
    quotes: [2, 'single', {'avoidEscape': true, 'allowTemplateLiterals': true}],
    'semi-spacing': ['warn', {'before': false, 'after': true}],
    semi: ['warn', 'always'],
```
yuck
power is ugly
I agree with having consistency in terms of style in the same codebase
I dont agree in having ~100 customised rules
yeah it's a bit unreasonable on anything other than a large team
when it comes to styling, consensus >>> perfection
I just drop the ember-suave eslint plugin and continue with my life
I don't agree with ALL it's rules, but it's a standard in the community
so I eat my preferences
and ship
I just disable the array-destructuring, because sometimes is incredibly stupid and thinks that destructuring is always better
it should be limited to the second or third item max
beyond that point, using commas is just mental
gonna drop a little :bomb: here: I’ve never experienced stylistic linting rules to be anything but a waste of time
i think they're like fences, they make good neighbours
forces consensus in a team that would otherwise quibble

Interesting. For me, the value is removing the pointless code style opinions taking over PR reviews. Removing that stuff from the team's conscious means that they can focus on what matters. If you can't code your rule in a linter and convince the team it's worth running, then don't bother bringing it up in a PR. That's where I've found the value to be.

attachments.fallback: [October 10th, 2016 4:57 PM] jgwhite: gonna drop a little :bomb: here: I’ve never experienced stylistic linting rules to be anything but a waste of time
attachments.text: gonna drop a little :bomb: here: I’ve never experienced stylistic linting rules to be anything but a waste of time

text: right, perhaps I’ve not worked on teams that were as interested in nitpicky styles
basically every time one of these things was introduced, it led to way more bikeshedding over linter rules than we ever had before about stylistic niggles
but maybe we were all fairly relaxed about code style
somewhere in the world "spaces versus tabs" ended a marriage
haha
IMO linting is double-edged sword. With some teams it works well and others its bike-shedding territory.
The best situation I've seen is some basic linting that *isn't* run on CI.
Its a recommendation before PRs but its not going to fail the build because you decided to go off the beaten track.
that sounds very reasonable to me
did you ever use something like Hound where it will actually leave comments on the PR automatically?
Great for new hires too. Little confidence boost that your code "passes" the lint.
but your grizzled tech lead don't have time for that.
Hound was incredibly noisy for very little practical benefit
I think it comes down to team size.
At a certain size your team keeps you in check.
Hound is like working with a stickler for detail – friendly, nice, useful.... unless your trying to get stuff done –
haha — exactly
I’m slightly playing devil’s advocate with all thise

though I do think the high order bit is what <@U043AB2QT> said:
> Removing that stuff from the team's conscious means that they can focus on what matters
^ and I feel like this is good advice for an individual too
I certainly reached a point in my career where I learned to look beyond the nitpicks, and have been much less of a git since
(I hope)
<@U03V8V08M> best bomb ever
depends, there some rules that are more about styles (spaces before/after braces p.e.)
and other that linting rules have code-quality value
by example, disallow `var`
that said, `if(condition)` is obviously wrong for any sane person
`if (condition)` if right
if anyone argues with that: I demand a trial by combat
